I always thought having an intern is like tipping: if you can't afford to leave a tip, you eat at home. If you can't afford to pay your intern, you don't have one.

A few years ago I interned for my state's senator in Washington. I got paid minimum wage but the senator's office also paid for my Metro transportation. While I just barely paid the bill with the minimum wage salary, I experience and education I gained by working on the hill was hugely rewarding. I wouldn't have been able to have had this experience if I had had to work for free. I did valuable work (answering phones, scheduling, constituent correspondence) that deserved to be paid. No one should work for free. It's called slavery.

As a current college student, I have had nearly ten internships and most of them have been unpaid. The main issue is the socioeconomic barrier that unpaid internships create by forcing students who cannot afford to work for free, to lose out on unbelievable opportunities.

Read more at http://www.nycprintern.com

Real federal expenditures were down from the previous quarter, which perhaps not coincidentally was the last quarter to come in before the election, but they were still higher than the previous year's 4th quarter. There was no drop in federal spending this year. Civilian spending grew year over year by more than defense spending dropped.

And whose idea was it to cut defense spending? One of the most logical forms of stimulus spending would be too replenish depleted weapons stocks during a period of slow growth rather than faster growth when those workers should be freed up for civilian industry.
President Obama is falling into  the same trap as FDR. FDR followed the deficit hawks and  started Cutting governemnt before it was ready, and  almost sent  the country into a second depression.

Paul Krugman has been warning about the ill-effects of austerity in these very pages for quite some time. He's been warning us by teaching us about economics and using the example of the various European nations that have tried it. He has described at length and in great detail the effects austerity has had. The GOP hasn't listened. Quite to the contrary, they've intensified their push for cuts in the budget. In their view, the people must suffer and suffer greatly.

People have been suffering all along, with banks that won't lend to small and mid-sized businesses, and large businesses not hiring workers.

In his column today, Robert Kuttner of The American Prospect writes:

"What exactly happened in the last quarter of 2012 to cause the recovery not just to stall -- but to actually shrink the economy by a tenth of a point? According to the Commerce Department, there were multiple factors.

Exports slumped, business purchases to replenish inventory slowed, but here is the sentence that screams out: "Real federal government consumption expenditures and gross investment decreased 15.0 percent in the fourth quarter, in contrast to an increase of 9.5 percent in the third." In other words, cut government spending and you undermine a fragile recovery."

What Mr. Kuttner describes is the effect of a small contraction in government spending. The effect of a sequester would be vastly larger.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/robert-kuttner/weak-economy-wrong-debate_b...

1. The job losses are already starting. Federal agencies are reducing their support for private contractors, and the contractors are laying people off. Ironically, this first round of job losses is in the private sector.

2. The sequester spreads the cuts throughout government, rather than focusing the cuts on inefficient or ineffective programs. That is just plain stupid.

3. Precious funds are also being used to plan and manage the sequester process, leaving even less for program operations.

4. While Tea Party members of Congress deserve a special measure of opprobrium for the sequester, there's substantial blame to go around. President Obama's decision to make Simpson-Bowles a centerpiece of his domestic policy in late 2010 helped to shift political concern from economic growth and jobs to deficit reduction, thus paving the way for the sequester.

I truly believe there is no substitute for hard work, no matter where you get your education. I know folks that have ivy league degrees and it has gotten them no where, and folks that went the route of Mr. Brooks and have had great success in their career.  I fall in the latter category myself and although I'm embarrassed at times to say where I went to school (mainly because no one has ever heard of it) I'm grateful for the education I got and how well my career has gone. None of it, however, came easy.  Guts, determination, relentlessness and hard, hard work.

OoooBoy!  Look at all the negative comments!  Does anyone out there feel threatened?  Maybe?  In my considerable experience, the wasteland is the residence colleges and universities.  I don't remember a single inspiring interchange with fellow students or faculty, and when I became faculty I discovered the most insanely vicioua backbiting political jungle there is.  No intellectual grasp, just grasping for prestige and power.  And as for no interchange with the online courses?  Ever heard of a chat room?  I'm presently studying a subject that fascinates me, for free (Coursera, thankyou) with students from all over the world, many of them insanely over qualified, and all of us there for one reason only, to learn.  As for my conventionally acquired degrees?  Not worth the liquid to dampen the paper.
Doesn't say it won't either.  And you are claiming traditional education models work for what % and produce what level of meaningful education?
A degree.  That's what you get from a traditional institution too.  The education is up to you.

There are many comments about the value of 'going away to school' and interacting with people with similar goals or different points of view, exposure is the key ingredient. While this is valuable, and contributes to learning, do I need to pay a university for this privilege? What if you lived in a building full of people who were all taking classes, working pt jobs, and having intellectually stimulating conversations? 'Campus life' can be created by real estate developers as much as the Dean...as evidenced by universities joint venturing or acting as de facto RE Developers. The cost and format of the classes really would not matter in my opinion.

My job involves interacting online with people on multiple continents and I'll never meet most of them. That does not prevent us from exchanging ideas and working towards common goals. The Classroom format is kind of an anachronism and so is the highly paid professor who teaches for 3 hours a week then retreats to his wood paneled office.

When huge universities are operating with multi Billion dollar endowments why charge tuition? Why do they need federal support? There is a lot of dysfunction and the faculty is not leading a charge to change their lifestyle by any means...its time for a different model, it doesnt have to be a universal model but it needs to be an option for the 98% who cant afford a 60k/yr tuition to land a 40k/yr job.

A standard issue Tom Friedman paean to the power of technology. I hope he's right in his very optimistic assertion that these new tools will empower citizens of the world to demand "real rights and decent governance." I'm not so sure that's what we see happening here in the US. And as always when reading one of his columns, I have to wonder - does Mr. Friedman know anyone who actually works for a living? His time seems to be spent jetting between continents meeting CEOs, CFOs, CIOs, government big shots, international consultants, and "social entrepreneurs." I get the feeling the only time he talks to someone with a regular job is when he says hello to the doorman.

In  India  even beggers have cell phones, but that does not make them  members of middle class. I don't know what Tom Friedman's fetish about cell phones is ? I live comfortably here in US and don't use cell phones. In fact I hate them. So even if  farmers in India may own cell phones, but thousands of them also committ suicides every year .

300 million people -- the "virtual middle class" in Mr.Friedman's word -- had remained invisible to the journalist until they owned cellphone or voiced their views. What a power of journalistic observation!

But Mr.Friedman is not the only one with selective blindness. The upper segment of Indian population, except few, had remained blind to the rest of the society, their abysmal deprivation. Mr.Friedman paints the progress in economic terms -- but misses the essential point that human dignity is not a function of economic status.

A man is a man with or without a cellphone. But Mr.Friedman and his ilk fail to recognize that basic truth and knowingly or unknowingly perpetuate the inequity and abuse of human dignity in one of the most populous and now prosperous nation.

Having commuted to India for 10 years (because 25% of our developers are there, and because I consult to 3 Indian Wireless companies) I can attest to Professor Friedman"s thesis on technology being a correct one.

Cheap cellular has absolutely transformed this country, but It is the catalyst to decades of effort by the government to promote literacy. For boys and for girls. Americans would be surprised to know just how literate the people of India are.

But with poor communications infrastructure and a business culture of bribes and corruption, it was hard to leverage that education. Mobile phones absolutely changed that. If you listen to Indians on their cells they are talking business, making deals, 24/7.

Say something to your driver about something you want, and he is on his mobile in a New York minute to get you what you need with 6 different options.

You don't have to travel to Mumbai to see this. Go to Mexico City. The same dynamic.

I also go to alot of, shall we say, "quieter corners" of the US, because Telecom's like to put their facilities there. What I see are teenagers and adults blathering on their cell phones out of sheer boredom. This scares me.

Technology only enables what is inherent in the culture and society

A middle class is the inflection point between the first world and the third world, and if you travel extensively you will see the undeniable reality that we should be prepared for massive change.

The anomalous results in Arizona, where Democrats received only 43% of the House popular vote (vs. 52% for Republicans), yet won 5 out of 9 seats, arguably arose from a different cause. After the chair of the independent redistricting commission was fired by Gov. Jan Brewer, but reinstated by the Arizona Supreme Court, no Republican candidate ran in District 7, the state's most heavily Democratic one. This district covers southwestern Arizona, Yuma, and the largest part of the border with Mexico, is majority Hispanic, and contains seven sovereign Native American nations. Democratic incumbent Ed Pastor won with 82% of the vote, vs. 18% for his Libertarian opponent. Of the remaining districts, Republicans won 4 with large margins and Democrats won 4 with relatively small margins. Although some might claim, with Gov. Brewer, that the redistricting commission engaged in gerrymandering, a more plausible explanation is that the Arizona Republican Party acknowledged the toxicity of its brand in that part of the state, and directed its campaign resources elsewhere.

An even greater usurpation of the democratic process is the two party primary system. Nearly a third of all voters self describe themselves as independents, but the two party primary is designed to disenfranchise them. The system in place selects for  candidates from extremes with the result that gridlock in Congress should be no surprise. What we need is a single open primary, where all the candidates run against each other and all voters are eligible to participate (this is supposed to be a democracy isn't it?); with the top two facing off in the general election in the fall. With all the votes in play in the primary this would force candidates to moderate their positions and give voters in the middle a chance at fair representation. And by the way, the single open primary is something else that has already been adopted by California.
